text.textblock: Wash hands after contact with mucous membranes, respiratory secretions, or objects contaminated with respiratory secretions, whether or not gloves are worn. Wash hands before and after contact with a patient who has an endotracheal or tracheostomy tube in place, and before and after contact with any respiratory device that is used on the patient, whether or not gloves are worn.
a. Wear gloves for handling respiratory secretions or objects contaminated with respiratory secretions of any patient.

b. Change gloves and wash hands between patients; after handling respiratory secretions or objects contaminated with secretions from one patient and before contact with another patient, object, or environmental surface; and between contacts with a contaminated body site and respiratory tract of, or respiratory device on, the same patient.
c. Wear a gown when soiling with respiratory secretions from a patient is anticipated, and change the gown after such contact and before providing care to another patient.
a. Perform tracheostomy under sterile conditions.
b. When changing a tracheostomy tube, use aseptic technique and replace the tube with one that has undergone sterilization or high-level disinfection.

b. If the open suction system is employed, use a sterile single-use catheter.
c. Use only sterile fluid to remove secretions from the suction catheter.
d. Change suction-collection tubing and canisters between patients.

III. Modifying Host Risk for Infection
A. Precautions for Prevention of Endogenous Pneumonia
a. Discontinue enteral-tube feeding and remove devices such as endotracheal and/or nasogastric or other enteral tubes from patients as soon as the clinical indications for these are resolved.
b. If there is no contraindication to the maneuver, elevate at an angle of 30-45
â—‹ the head of the bed of a patient who is receiving mechanically assisted ventilation and has a nasogastric or other enteral tube in place.
c. Routinely verify appropriate placement of the feeding tube.

d. Routinely assess the patient's intestinal motility, (e.g., by auscultating for bowel sounds and measuring residual gastric volume or abdominal girth) and adjust the rate and volume of enteral feeding to avoid regurgitation.
e. Use small-bore tubes for enteral feeding;
f. Administer enteral feeding intermittently in small quantities, rather than continuously.
